node.title: Police search for woman missing for six days
node.description: Police are continuing to scour central Auckland suburbs to find a woman missing since last week.

node.title: Murihiku-Southland's Polyfest goes fully online
node.description: The event was planned to run in Invercargill in September but organisers Mīharo moved it online due to alert-level 2 restrictions.

node.title: More policy needed in Defence operations: Minister accepts review recommendations
node.description: The Defence Force needs closer connection to the ministry so that policy can help guide on-the-ground operations, a review has found.

node.title: Principal faces 'awful vindictive' abuse for supporting vaccine mandate
node.description: A Northland high school principal says she has been accused of being "complicit in mass genocide" by people opposed to getting vaccinated.

node.title: Colorado’s governor says he is ‘frustrated’ with federal regulators about booster eligibility.
node.description: Federal regulators are considering a request to make all adults eligible for Pfizer-BioNTech’s Covid boosters. Colorado and two other states decided to broaden access anyway.

node.title: Trump to Sell Marquee Washington Hotel for at Least $375 Million
node.description: The pending deal to sell the Trump International Hotel, often the subject of controversy during his presidency, comes after years of financial losses at the property.

node.title: PM defends Senate ABC inquiry, Ita Buttrose says it's an attempt to 'mute' the national broadcaster
node.description: Scott Morrison says no government agency is above scrutiny, as Ita Buttrose labels a Senate inquiry a "partisan" attempt to undermine the national broadcaster.

node.title: 'Australia's most homophobic town' raises pride flag after controversial history
node.description: A town once the flashpoint for the debate on decriminalising homosexuality in Tasmania raises the rainbow pride flag over its council chambers, marking a change in attitudes after gay locals grew up there and copped abuse daily.

node.title: Body modifier found guilty of female genital mutilation
node.description: Brendan Russell is found guilty of female genital mutilation after a judge rejects his lawyer's argument that laws prohibiting the practice are intended to be limited to children.

node.title: Boat debris, esky message ends two-day stranding deep in croc territory
node.description: The two men lost their EPIRB and mobile phones after their boat sank in the remote Northern Territory. The men then spent two nights on an island without any food or fresh water before another vessel came across their debris.

node.title: 'Where is she? Is she safe?': Concerns for Chinese tennis player who claimed politician sexually assaulted her
node.description: The WTA says the Chinese government must conduct a full investigation into sexual allegations made by tennis star Peng Shuai against a former senior Chinese official.

node.title: Target for 90% Covid-19 vaccination not 'anywhere near enough' - expert
node.description: The race is on to get 90 percent of all eligible residents of all DHBs fully vaccinated against Covid-19, but even if that happens, one in four New Zealanders will still be unvaccinated.

node.title: Andrew Sullivan on American political discourse and conservatism in 2021
node.description: Andrew Sullivan says American democracy is at risk because citizens can't compromise or separate politics from life.

node.title: New documentary shows making of Beatles' album "Let It Be"
node.description: Hours of unseen footage of the Beatles' writing and recording are being released after 50 years, part of Peter Jackson's new documentary, "Get Back." Jon Wertheim reports.

node.title: Inside the issues causing the U.S. supply chain crisis
node.description: 60 Minutes follows the U.S.'s struggling supply chain, from choked ports on the West Coast, to packed rail yards in Chicago. We found finger-pointing, huge profits and massive losses.

node.title: Sinema to attend White House infrastructure bill signing
node.description: President Biden is set to sign the $1.25 trillion bipartisan infrastructure bill on Monday.

node.title: Faith Groups Push to Scrap New Mandates in Biden’s Child Care Plan
node.description: A nondiscrimination provision in the $1.85 trillion social policy bill could disqualify some religious organizations, which provide more than half of child care programs in the United States.

node.title: Biden Names Mitch Landrieu to Oversee Infrastructure Spending
node.description: Mr. Landrieu, a former mayor of New Orleans, will supervise the distribution of funds from the bipartisan legislation that the president will sign into law on Monday.

node.title: Japan’s Economy Shrinks, but Outlook Is Warm as Virus Ebbs
node.description: The coronavirus and supply chain issues stymied growth in the third quarter, but high vaccination rates and low numbers of virus cases point to a recovery.

node.title: 19 Incredible Photos Giving a Window Into 19th Century New York
node.description: Take a tour of New York City in the 1800s.

node.title: Dad 'Grabbed Our Daughter and Protected Her,' Says Mom After Child Sole-Survivor in Plane Crash
node.description: "It's her last memory before the crash," the 11-year-old's mother said. "He gave the best bear hugs."

node.title: Elon Musk offers to sell more stock after telling Bernie Sanders he forgot 'you're still alive'
node.description: Tesla chief executive Elon Musk spars with former US presidential hopeful Bernie Sanders, after the latter called for billionaires to pay more tax.

node.title: Tech billionaire Mike Cannon-Brookes buys stake in Rabbitohs
node.description: The entrepreneur and philanthropist says he is "excited and humbled" to become part of the club, of which he has been a long-time supporter.

node.title: COP26: New global climate deal struck in Glasgow
node.description: A deal aimed at staving off dangerous climate change has been struck at the COP26 summit in Glasgow.

node.title: The Queen to miss Remembrance Sunday service
node.description: The Queen will no longer attend the Remembrance Sunday service at the Cenotaph in London as she has sprained her back.

node.title: Invercargill councillors vote to move away from external appointees
node.description: Invercargill City Council is preparing to take off its training wheels after a tumultuous period that included potential government intervention.

node.title: Review: This Revival of Sondheim’s ‘Assassins’ Misses Its Mark
node.description: The production lacks the power to unsettle despite a fine cast of killers and wannabes who changed, or at least made, history gunning for presidents.

node.title: Dozens of N.Y.C. sanitation workers were suspended during an inquiry into the use of fake vaccine cards.
node.description: It is the latest chapter in the protracted debate over the city’s vaccine mandate for municipal workers.

node.title: Queensland brings forward softening of border rules with passes available from this afternoon
node.description: The Queensland government brings forward the opening of the state's border to some fully vaccinated travellers from interstate COVID-19 hotspots, with people able to apply for their border passes from 5:00pm today.

node.title: William Tyrrell search renewed by police, seven years after his disappearance
node.description: A new search is planned for William Tyrrell, missing from his foster-grandmother's home since 2014, police announce.

node.title: It has taken 52 years, but bank heist mystery finally solved
node.description: US authorities have solved a bank heist mystery that stumped investigators for more than five decades.

node.title: Focus on Politics: Family Court frustrations stoke calls for change
node.description: Podcast - As the Family Court nears its 40th anniversary, lawyers' say the system falls short of its own standards and Māori leaders say their calls for change have not been heard. Anneke Smith report… Audio

node.title: Government to address 'quirk' in new one-off residence visa
node.description: The government says it will look at a 'quirk' in immigration policy that means some workers have to leave the country and fly back in to be eligible for next year's one-off residence visa.

node.title: Project to fix Carillon tower extended by five years
node.description: A 50m-tall tower with 70 tonnes of bells in it that presents a high earthquake risk in central Wellington has been approved to stay that way for up to six years.

node.title: Warnings over finance course spreading in Māori, Pasifika community
node.description: A Hamilton woman living in the US admits she targets single mothers, Māori and Pasifika to join a finance course that international regulators have likened to a pyramid scam.

node.title: Climate Promises Made in Glasgow Now Rest With a Handful of Powerful Leaders
node.description: In Washington, Beijing, New Delhi and beyond, governments face conflicting forces — political, social and economic — that will shape their next steps in the effort to avert a climate crisis.

node.title: Steve Bannon Indictment Already Compelling Witnesses to Answer Subpoenas: Adam Schiff
node.description: "I view this as an early test of whether democracy was recovering," Schiff said Sunday.

node.title: 'Convoluted Messaging' on Booster Shots Draws Criticism: 'The Data Is Incredibly Clear'
node.description: "The confusing message around the boosters may end up being one of the biggest missed opportunities in this pandemic," Scott Gottlieb said Sunday.

node.title: SA authorities announce extra details for state border reopening
node.description: South Australian authorities provide further details around the state's border reopening plan, due to come into effect on November 23.

node.title: Parekōwhai work sets NZ art auction record
node.description: 'A Peak in Darien' sold for a record $2.05 million and two McCahon works fetched in excess of $1m each at Art + Object's weekend auction.

node.title: 'A workman-like job' - Mixed reaction to COP26 in New Zealand
node.description: The outcome of the COP26 climate summit won't help anyone sleep at night with the world still on track for catastrophic warming, but New Zealand observers say there has been some good out of it.

node.title: Austria orders lockdown for unvaccinated residents
node.description: The move prohibits unvaccinated people 12 and older from leaving their homes except for basic activities such as working, grocery shopping, going for a walk — or getting vaccinated.

node.title: Irene is one of Australia's most in-demand workers right now. Here's why
node.description: As a registered nurse, Irene McInerney's skill set is one of the most sought after in the nation. But like millions of other workers, she's feeling the strain of the labour shortage, which has left experts reeling.

node.title: Tesla boss praises New Zealand's EV efforts
node.description: The head of the world's leading electric vehicle maker has heaped praise on New Zealand for its efforts to electrify the country's vehicle fleet and cut emissions.

node.title: COP26: How might decisions at the climate summit change our lives?
node.description: A deal has been made at the climate summit in Glasgow, but what will that mean for the average person?

node.title: Jamie Wall: All Blacks drown in the Green Room
node.description: Ireland have beaten the All Blacks for the third time in five years. Jamie Wall  writes it's not so much that New Zealand played particularly badly, it's that they were barely allowed to play at all.

node.title: Lee Maracle, Combative Indigenous Author, Dies at 71
node.description: She collected signatures to persuade publishers that people would buy her books. She became a foundational figure in Indigenous literature.
